Award.AwardTitle: Evolutionary dynamics of collateral gene silencing by piRNA

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Transposable elements (TE) are DNA sequences that can change their position in the genome and thereby produce a variety of harmful mutations. Animals, including fruit flies, have evolved a defense mechanism to guard against TE movement whereby small RNAs, called piRNAs, can destroy essential RNA intermediates produced by the TEs. Exactly how piRNAs work is not well understood, and the overall aim of this project is to study how piRNAs specifically target TE RNAs without destroying beneficial RNAs. The research has the potential to provide valuable insights into prevention of harmful mutations that could cause genetic defects or death. The project will have broader impacts for undergraduates, graduate students and a postdoctoral researcher, who will receive training in genetics, evolution and bioinformatics. Added benefit will derive from production of internet videos that will serve as general tools for education about various topics in genetics and evolution.

piRNAs play a critical role in genome defense by destroying TE RNAs. This research will determine how the piRNA defense mechanism is constrained by the harm that occurs when piRNAs mistakenly target RNAs from normal genes and thus result in off-target, or collateral, gene silencing. Using different species of Drosophila as a model, the work will test the hypothesis that species with high TE content are more affected by these collateral effects. One series of experiments will determine whether species with higher TE content have less variation in expression of the piRNA machinery, increased silencing by piRNA, and stronger maternal effects on gene expression. Other experiments, in which piRNA expression is artificially increased, will reveal whether there is a functional tradeoff between genome defense and off-target effects. This work will provide important information about how the mechanisms that protect the genome are governed by the harmful effects of collateral gene silencing, which can be considered to be a form of "genomic autoimmunity".

POR.DRECONTENT:
In sexually reproducing organisms, selfish elements known as transposable elements (TEs) have the capacity to proliferate within genomes. Because they can cause harm through mutation and chromosomal damage, specialized systems of small RNA-mediated defense have evolved to limit their movement. This project focused on the evolution of one particular small RNA-based mode of genome defense - that depending on a particular class of RNAs known as piwi-interacting RNAs (piRNAs).

 

A striking observation over the past decade is that systems of piRNA-mediated genome defense are rapidly evolving. Moreover, their rapid evolution appears to be driven by a very strong pattern of adaptive evolution. What drives this rapid evolution is unclear, but one hypothesis is that a host-parasite arms race with TEs is responsible. Under this scenario, the piRNA machinery evolves rapidly to respond to newly evolved TE strategies for the evasion of piRNA silencing. We have proposed an alternative hypothesis. Instead of a one-to-one co-evolutionary process with distinct TE lineages, we propose that systems of genome defense adapt to a shifting landscape of total TE burden. We hypothesize that as bulk genomic abundance of TEs increases, the piRNA machinery must adapt to ensure genes do not also become off-targets of genome defense. As bulk abundance of TEs decreases, selection will favor the piRNA machinery to become more sensitive to invading TEs because it is less likely that genes will be silenced incorrectly. We propose that adaptive evolution in the piRNA machinery is driven by fluctuating strategies under a shifting landscape of genomic TE abundance.

 

We have tested this alternate hypothesis several ways. First, under a co-evolutionary process, one might predict that the signature of adaptive evolution is strongest in species with greater TE abundance. By examining signatures of adaptive evolution, we found instead that rates of adaptation are similar in species with high and low TE burden. This indicates that a high rate of adaptation is not solely driven by a large number of TEs. Even in cases where TE abundance is low, the piRNA machinery shows a strong signature of adaptation. This suggests that the host-parasites arms race model for adaptive evolution of the piRNA machinery may be incorrect. Second, we have examined piRNA biogenesis across different species of Drosophila with varying TE burden. We have made two discoveries. First, the piRNA machinery has a strong signature of increased translational efficiency in species with greater TE abundance. Second, the length of piRNAs is correlated with TE abundance. In particular, species with greater TE abundance have longer piRNAs. This supports a model in which specificity for TE silencing is a strong target of selection in species with greater TE abundance. Finally, we have found that increased genomic TE burden does not lead to an increased burden of gene silencing by piRNA. Overall, these results support a model in which adaptation in the piRNA machinery is driven by shifting costs of off-target gene silencing rather than a co-evolutionary process driven by host-parasite dynamics. We are now validating these results with genetically modified strains of Drosophila that overexpress the piRNA machinery. These strains were produced under this project.

 

In addition to these outcomes, the project led to further discoveries regarding the evolution of transposable elements and piRNA silencing. These include an evolutionary analysis of the core protein complex that holds homologous chromosomes together during meiosis and the demonstration that expression of the piRNA machinery increases as female Drosophila age. Theoretical studies supported by this project also demonstrated that, in contrast to models that suggest drift determines TE burden, horizontal transfer can lead to increased TE abundance in large populations. This theoretical study provides an important underpinning to the hypothesis that changing exposure to TEs - not evolution of TEs themselves - is likely to drive adaptive evolution in the piRNA machinery.

 

Finally, a significant broader impact of the project is the contribution to education and training. Two graduate students and one technician were trained under this project. The technician has now entered graduate school, one graduate student has become a postdoctoral researcher and a second graduate student now works in local biomedical workforce development. In addition, twelve undergraduates have contributed to this project. One student is an author of a paper and authorship is expected for six additional students. Of these twelve students, four are members of underrepresented groups. This project also supported the development of an improved Honors Genetics curriculum at the University of Kansas that trains students in simulation in the R programming language.
